case_data.name: MadKudu Inc. v. U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
case_data.plaintiff_description: All U.S. employers who in 2019 through December 6, 2020 filed, or will file, a petition with USCIS for an H-1B classification under 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b) for a market research analyst where: USCIS denied or will deny the petition based on a finding that the OOH entry for market research analyst does not establish that the occupation is a specialty occupation, and thus does not satisfy 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1); and But for this finding, the petition would be approved.
case_data.summary:
This was a nationwide class action filed by U.S. businesses that challenged the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services's (USCIS) pattern and practice of arbitrarily denying H-1B nonimmigrant employment-based petitions to classify market research analyst positions as "specialty occupations." On April 16, 2020, companies who had such petitions denied filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. Plaintiffs sued USCIS and their Senior Official Performing the Duties of the Director under the Declaratory Judgment Act, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act. Represented by the National Immigration Litigation Alliance, the American Immigration Lawyers Association, the American Immigration Council, and private counsel, plaintiffs asked the court to set aside and vacate the denials of plaintiffs’ and class members' H-1B petitions, to declare that the defendants unlawfully engaged in a pattern and practice of misapplying the law, to enjoin defendants from its interpretation of relevant petition criteria to deny petitions for market research analysts, and to award attorneys’ fees. The case was assigned to Magistrate Judge Susan van Keulen.

H-1B immigrant visa classification allows highly educated noncitizens to work for American employers in specialty occupations. Specialty occupations are those that require particular knowledge and skills for which a bachelor’s degree or higher (or its equivalent) in a specific specialty is required. USCIS had allegedly been arbitrarily denying these plaintiffs' petitions regarding classification because they mistakenly found they did not satisfy the “first regulatory test,” which requires a bachelor’s degree in the specialty be typically required for such work as outlined by the Occupational Outlook Handbook (OOH). USCIS has been denying petitions on the grounds that several degrees or fields of study may qualify a person to work as a market research analyst, which would mean that the degree requirement is not a specific specialty. The plaintiffs argued that the fact that multiple degrees may prepare a person to be a market research analyst does not negate that the typical degrees attained by most who pursue the occupation are closely related to market research and therefore constitute a specialty.

The defendants moved to sever and dismiss the plaintiffs' claims on August 4, 2020. The defendants sought severance because they argued that the claims were impermissibily joindered and also moved for dismissal on the basis that two of the named plaintiffs' claims were mooted because their H-1B petitions were approved. On September 14, the court denied these motions. Specifically, the court held that permissive joinder was still valid as arising out of the same transaction or occurrence. The court similarly concluded that the plaintiffs whose petitions were granted retained an interest in the litigation because of the possibility that the allegedly wrongful behavior would recur.

Plaintiffs’ motion for class certification was granted in part on November 17, 2020. During the course of litigation, the Department of Homeland security issued an interim final rule amending the process for evaluating H-1B petitions, requiring a "direct relationship between degree field(s) and duties of the position." A petition would not be granted if the attainment of a general degree would suffice. Because the interim final rule altered the criteria underlying H-1B petitions, the court certified a narrow class that involved:

"All U.S. employers who in 2019 through December 6, 2020 filed, or will file, a petition (Form I-129 or any successor) with USCIS for an H-1B classification under 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b) for a market research analyst where: 

  • USCIS denied or will deny the petition solely or in part based on a finding that the OOH entry for market research analyst does not establish that the occupation is a specialty occupation, and thus does not satisfy 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1); and
  • But for this finding, the petition would be approved."

Plaintiffs were appointed as class representatives.

On August 20, 2021, the parties reached a settlement regarding the adjudication of future H-1B petitions for market research analyst positions. The settlement outlined that H-1B adjudicators would more expansively grant petitions claiming market research analyst positions to be specialty occupations. This included past denials, which the parties agreed could be reopened for potential class members. After a fairness hearing, Judge Susan van Keulen approved the final settlement agreement on October 19, 2021. The case was voluntarily dismissed by stipulation of the parties 3 days later. The court retained jurisdiction to settle disputes over the 5-year course of the settlement.
case_data.summary_short: In 2020, companies whose H-1B petitions for market research analysts were denied filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. Plaintiffs alleged that the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services engaged in a pattern and practice of arbitrarily denying such H-1B petitions because of a misinterpretation of the regulatory requirements. In 2021, the parties reached a settlement that clarified the guidelines for granting/denying H-1B petitions for market research analysts and outlined a procedure for reviewing prior denials.

1  vi.  Was the sole basis for the denial a determination that the position 
2  was not a specialty occupation? 
3  b.  If USCIS determines that the petitioner is not a class member according to 
4  the standards set forth in Section II.D.3.a, it may reject the reopening 
5  request. 
6  c.  A petitioner may indicate a new start date and end date for the validity 
7  period, as long as the new start date and end date falls within the period in 
8  the certified LCA previously submitted with the petition that the petitioner 
9  is seeking to reopen. USCIS must grant the petitioner’s request for a 
10  different start date and end date for the validity period if the date(s) 
11  requested by the petitioner falls within the period specified in the certified 
12  LCA previously submitted with the petition that the petitioner is seeking 
13  to reopen. 
14  d.  If USCIS finds that the petitioner is a class member and that there is time 
15  remaining on the period specified in the certified LCA, it must reopen the 
16  petition and re-adjudicate it under the standard set out in Section II.C.1 
17  supra. If an issue of fraud or willful misrepresentation comes to USCIS’ 
18  attention, it will reopen and send the petitioner an RFE or a Notice of 
19  Intent to Deny (“NOID”). 
20  e.  USCIS shall abide by the recent deference guidance issued by USCIS on 
21  April 27, 2021, in those cases involving the same parties and facts in 
22  which there was a prior approval. See 
23  https://www.uscis.gov/news/alerts/uscis-issues-policy-guidance-on-
24  deference-to-previous-decisions. In such cases, USCIS should defer to the 
25  prior approval unless there was a material error, material change, or a new 
26  material fact(s).  
27  f.  USCIS will not deny a named plaintiff’s case without first issuing a RFE 
28  or NOID and permitting the named plaintiff to submit additional 
  10 
 
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 85-1   Filed 08/20/21   Page 11 of 15
 
 
 
1  documentation and argument to show eligibility and qualification.  
2  4.  USCIS will decide all MadKudu class members’ reopening requests within 90 
3  days of its receipt of the physical file at the adjudicating office for all timely-filed 
4  reopening requests of class members in which, at the time that the class member submits 
5  the reopening request, there is any amount of time remaining on the period specified in 
6  the previously filed LCA. USCIS will attempt to prioritize reopening requests for 
7  petitions with LCAs expiring in less than 90 days after the reopening request is properly 
8  filed with USCIS. 
9  5.  For any MadKudu class member’s reopening request that USCIS intends to deny, 
10  USCIS will first send the petitioner a NOID identifying the ground for denial and provide 
11  the petitioner a period of 30 days from the notice date to respond. USCIS will decide the 
12  request within 60 days of its receipt of petitioner’s response to the NOID. 
13    E.  Notice to Class Members 
14  1.  The parties mutually will agree upon language for a Notice that explains the 
15  settlement to class members. 
16  2.  Prior to the Court holding a fairness hearing on the Settlement Agreement, USCIS 
17  will post this Notice on its website, along with a copy of the Settlement Agreement. 
18  USCIS then will update its website with a notice stating the outcome of the Court’s 
19  fairness hearing.  
20  3.  USCIS will announce the Settlement Agreement through its social media, 
21  directing readers to its website posting. 
22  4.  Plaintiffs will distribute the Notice and Settlement Agreement though various 
23  American Immigration Lawyers Association outlets and other relevant forums. 
24    F.  General Provisions 
25  1.  The Parties will submit the Settlement Agreement, the Notice to Class Members 
26  and a joint stipulation regarding the class definition, see B.1, to the Court for its approval. 
27  2.  Defendants will reopen and re-adjudicate Plaintiff Hanguang’s petition in 
28  accordance with Sections II.C.1 and II.D.3.c-f, within 14 days of the Court’s approval of 
  11 
 
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 85-1   Filed 08/20/21   Page 12 of 15
 
 
 
1  the Settlement Agreement. 
2  4.  Each party shall bear its own fees and costs. 
3  III.  DISPUTE RESOLUTION 
4  If there is a claim of a breach of this Settlement Agreement, the parties shall mutually resolve to 
5  address the matter within 90 calendar days of the date of notice of an alleged breach. The Court retains 
6  jurisdiction to resolve any disputes over enforcement of the Settlement Agreement that are not resolved 
7  between the parties pursuant to this section. 
8  IV.  EFFECTIVE DATE 
9  This Settlement Agreement will be effective on the date the Settlement Agreement receives final 
10  approval by the Court and shall remain in effect for a period of five (5) years beginning five (5) days 
11  after the date of approval. Subject to the dispute resolution and modification procedures in Sections III 
12  and VI.B, respectively, the Court retains jurisdiction to resolve any disputes over enforcement of the 
13  Settlement Agreement that arise and are presented to the Court during the effective period. 
14  V.  RELEASE: SCOPE AND EFFECT OF RELEASE 
15  As of the Effective Date, Plaintiffs and Class Members, on behalf of themselves, their heirs, 
16  executors, administrators, representatives, attorneys, successors, assigns, agents, affiliates, and partners, 
17  and any persons they represent, by operation of any final judgment entered by the Court, fully, finally, 
18  and forever release, relinquish, and discharge the Defendants of and from any and all of the Settled 
19  Claims. The foregoing release includes all claims for injunctive or declaratory relief relating to 
20  Defendants’ interpretation of the OOH entry for market research analysts challenged in this action, 
21  whether known or unknown, that could have been brought on behalf of Class Members at any time prior 
22  to the Effective Date. This Release shall not apply to claims that arise or accrue after the termination of 
23  this Settlement Agreement. 
24  VI.  ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS 
25  A.  This Settlement Agreement and the obligations incurred herein, shall be in full and final 
26  disposition of the Action with prejudice, including any and all Settled Claims against Defendants. On 
27  the Effective Date, Plaintiffs and Class Members shall be deemed to have fully, finally, and forever 
28  released, relinquished, and discharged Defendants of all Settled Claims. 
  12 
 
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 85-1   Filed 08/20/21   Page 13 of 15
 
 
 
1  B.  This Settlement Agreement may not be modified or amended, nor any of its provisions be 
2  waived, except by a writing signed by all parties hereto or their successors-in-interest. 
3  C.  This Settlement Agreement constitutes the entire agreement among the parties hereto 
4  concerning the settlement of the Action, and no representations, warranties, or inducements have been 
5  made by any party hereto other than those contained and memorialized in such documents. 
6  D.  This Settlement Agreement may be executed in one or more counterparts. All executed 
7  counterparts and each of them shall be deemed to be one and the same instrument provided that counsel 
8  for the parties to this Agreement shall exchange among themselves original signed counterparts. 
9  E.  This Settlement Agreement shall be binding upon, and inure to the benefit of, the 
10  successors and assigns of the parties hereto. 
11  F.  All counsel executing this Settlement Agreement warrant and represent that they have the 
12  full authority to do so, and that they have the authority to take appropriate action required or permitted 
13  to be taken under the Agreement to effectuate its terms. 
14  G.  Class Counsel and Defendants’ Counsel agree to cooperate fully with another in seeking 
15  Court approval of this Settlement Agreement and promptly agree upon and execute all such other 
16  documentation as reasonably may be required to obtain final approval by the Court of the settlement. 
17  VII.  SIGNATURES 
18  For and on behalf of Defendants:

15 
work for U.S. employers in specialty occupations. A specialty occupation is one which requires 
16 
the theoretical and practical application of a body of highly specialized knowledge for which a 
17 
bachelor’s or higher degree in a specific specialty (or its equivalent) is required. See 8 U.S.C. 
18 
§ 1184(i)(1). 
19

24 
normally the minimum requirement for entry into the particular position.” 8 C.F.R.

§ 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020) (hereinafter, the first regulatory test). Where Defendant USCIS

16.  Congress established a nonimmigrant classification to permit noncitizens to 
25 
temporarily perform services in the United States in specialty occupations. 8 U.S.C.

17.  A U.S. employer must follow a multi-step, two-agency process to obtain an H-1B 
1 
classification for a position it seeks to fill with a foreign worker. First, it must file a Labor 
2 
3  Condition Application with the U.S. Department of Labor in which it attests to standards to 
4  which it will adhere. On this application, the employer must identify the Standard Occupational 
5 
Classification (SOC) code and occupational title of the position it seeks to fill. The SOC system 
6 
is a federal statistical standard used by federal agencies to classify workers into occupational 
7 
categories for the purpose of collecting, calculating, or disseminating data.  
8 
18.  Upon the Department of Labor’s certification of the Labor Condition Application, 
9 
the U.S. employer will file it and an H-1B petition with Defendant USCIS. In its H-1B petition, 
10 
11  the U.S. employer petitioner must demonstrate by a preponderance of the evidence that the 
12 
position it seeks to fill is in a specialty occupation.  
13 
19.  A “specialty occupation” is one that requires the “(A) theoretical and practical 
14 
application of a body of highly specialized knowledge, and (B) attainment of a bachelor’s or 
15 
higher degree in the specific specialty (or its equivalent) as a minimum for entry into the 
16 
occupation in the United States.” 8 U.S.C. § 1184(i)(1). 
17 
18  20.  The regulatory definition of “specialty occupation” first repeats the statutory 
19  definition and then provides a non-exhaustive list of fields as examples of specialty occupations:   
20 
Specialty occupation means an occupation which requires theoretical and practical 
application of a body of highly specialized knowledge in fields of human endeavor 
21 
including, but not limited to, architecture, engineering, mathematics, physical sciences, 
22  social sciences, medicine and health, education, business specialties, accounting, law, 
theology, and the arts, and which requires the attainment of a bachelor's degree or higher 
23  in a specific specialty, or its equivalent, as a minimum for entry into the occupation in the 
United States.  
24 
8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(ii) (2020). 
25

4  A baccalaureate or higher degree or its equivalent is normally the minimum requirement

14

(2020); whether Defendant USCIS has a pattern and practice of denying the H-1B petitions of

INTRODUCTION 
1 
1.  Employing boilerplate language and uniform faulty reasoning, Defendant U.S. 
2 
Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) routinely and unlawfully denies nonimmigrant 
3 
employment-based petitions filed by U.S. employers under 8 U.S.C. §§ 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b), 
4 
5  1184(c)(1) and 1184(i), also known as H-1B petitions, to classify market research analyst 
6 
positions as a “specialty occupation.” Defendant USCIS’ denials violate the Immigration and 
7 
Nationality Act (INA) and implementing regulations, and the Administrative Procedure Act 
8 
(APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701, et seq. Plaintiffs MadKudu Inc., Quick Fitting, Inc., 2nd Street USA, 
9 
Inc., and Hanguang International Inc., four U.S. corporations, challenge Defendant USCIS’ 
10 
denial of H-1B petitions they filed on behalf of noncitizens they sought to hire in the market 
11 
12  research analyst occupation, as well as Defendant USCIS’ pattern and practice of arbitrarily and 
13  unlawfully denying petitions for market research analysts filed by similarly situated H-1B 
14 
petitioners.   
15 
2.  The H-1B nonimmigrant visa classification allows highly educated noncitizens to 
16 
work for U.S. employers in specialty occupations. A specialty occupation is one which requires 
17 
the theoretical and practical application of a body of highly specialized knowledge for which a 
18 
bachelor’s or higher degree in a specific specialty (or its equivalent) is required. See 8 U.S.C. 
19 
20  § 1184(i)(1). 
21  3.  By regulation, a U.S. employer petitioner can establish that a position is within a 
22 
specialty occupation through any one of several tests set forth in the governing regulation. 
23 
8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A) (2020). Relevant here is the first test, which authorizes a position 
24 
to qualify as a specialty occupation if “[a] baccalaureate or higher degree or its equivalent is 
25 
normally the minimum requirement for entry into the particular position.” 8 C.F.R. 
26 
§ 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020) (hereinafter, the first regulatory test). Where Defendant USCIS 
27 
Pls. Am. Compl. for Decl. and Inj. Relief                                   Case No. 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   
 
Page 3 
  
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 39   Filed 07/20/20   Page 4 of 26
 
 
determines that a U.S. employer petitioner satisfies this test, it has demonstrated that the 
1 
occupation is a “specialty occupation” and it can hire a qualified noncitizen to fill the position.  
2 
3  4.  In denying H-1B petitions for market research analysts, Defendant USCIS relies 
4  on the Occupational Outlook Handbook (OOH), a publication of the Bureau of Labor Statistics 
5 
of the U.S. Department of Labor, as an authoritative source on the educational requirements for 
6 
the occupations which it profiles. Defendant USCIS thus relies upon it to determine if a 
7 
bachelor’s or higher degree in a specific specialty, or its equivalent, is normally required for 
8 
entry into the occupation, thus satisfying the first regulatory test.  
9 
5.  The OOH’s profile of the market research analyst occupation demonstrates that 
10 
11  this occupation satisfies the first regulatory test; that is, it demonstrates that a bachelor’s degree 
12 
in a specific specialty—market research or a related field—is typically, or normally, required for 
13 
work as a market research analyst.  
14 
6.  Defendant USCIS has a pattern and practice of misinterpreting the OOH’s profile 
15 
of a market research analyst, mistakenly finding that it does not demonstrate that this occupation 
16 
satisfies the first regulatory test. In so finding, Defendant USCIS also has a pattern and practice 
17 
18  of misinterpreting the INA, 8 U.S.C. § 1184(i)(1), and the first regulatory test, 8 C.F.R. 
19  § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020).  
20 
7.  Had Defendant USCIS correctly applied the first regulatory test and found that the 
21 
occupation was a specialty occupation in Plaintiffs’ and putative class members’ cases, it would 
22 
have approved their petitions. Plaintiffs seek relief under the APA and the Declaratory Judgment 
23 
Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201-2202, on behalf of themselves and putative class members to remedy 
24 
Defendants’ misapplication of the specialty occupation statute and regulations and its 
25 
26  misinterpretation of the OOH.   
27 
Pls. Am. Compl. for Decl. and Inj. Relief                                   Case No. 5:20-cv-02653-SVK

JURISDICTION 
1 
8.  This case arises under the INA, 8 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., and the APA, 5 U.S.C. 
2 
§ 701 et seq. This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this action pursuant to 
3 
4  28 U.S.C. § 1331 (federal question jurisdiction). This Court has authority to grant relief under 
5  the APA and the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201-02. The United States has 
6 
waived sovereign immunity under 5 U.S.C. § 702. 
7 
VENUE 
8 
9.  Venue in this judicial district is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1)(C) because 
9 
Defendants are a U.S. agency and an officer of a U.S. agency acting in his official capacity, 
10 
Plaintiff MadKudu Inc. resides in this District, and no real property is involved in this action. 
11 
12  INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
13  10.  This action is properly assigned to the San Jose Division of this Court as Plaintiff 
14 
MadKudu Inc. resides in Santa Clara County and a substantial part of the events which give rise 
15 
to this claim occurred in Santa Clara County. 
16 
FINAL AGENCY ACTION AND  
17  EXHAUSTION OF ADMINISTRATIVE REMEDIES 
 
18 
11.  Defendant USCIS’ denial of Plaintiffs’ and putative class members’ H-1B 
19 
petitions constitutes final agency action under the APA, as does its policy, pattern and/or practice 
20 
regarding its adjudications of H-1B petitions for market research analysts. See 5 U.S.C. §§ 
21 
551(13); 701(b)(2); 704. Neither the INA nor implementing regulations require an administrative 
22 
23  appeal of the denials. Accordingly, Plaintiffs have no further administrative remedies to exhaust.   
24  PARTIES 
 
25 
12.  Plaintiff MadKudu Inc. is a marketing analytics software company headquartered 
26 
in Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California. MadKudu filed an H-1B petition for a 
27

position in the market research analyst occupation on or about April 2, 2019, which Defendant 
1 
USCIS denied on February 24, 2020 for, inter alia, failing to demonstrate that the position 
2 
3  satisfied 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020), the first regulatory test for a specialty 
4  occupation.  
5 
13.  Plaintiff Quick Fitting, Inc. is a supplier of plumbing fittings headquartered in 
6 
Warwick, Rhode Island. Quick Fitting filed an H-1B petition for a market research analyst on or 
7 
about August 20, 2019, which Defendant USCIS denied on January 23, 2020 for, inter alia, 
8 
failing to demonstrate that the position satisfied 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020), the first 
9 
regulatory test for a specialty occupation. 
10 
11  14.  Plaintiff 2nd Street USA, Inc. operates and manages six second-hand clothing 
12 
retail stores, one in New York and the others in Southern California, with headquarters in Los 
13 
Angeles, California. 2nd Street USA filed an H-1B petition for a position in the market research 
14 
analyst occupation on or about April 11, 2019, which Defendant USCIS denied on September 
15 
12, 2019 for, inter alia, failing to demonstrate that the position satisfied 8 C.F.R. 
16 
§ 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020), the first regulatory test for a specialty occupation. 
17 
18  15.  Plaintiff Hanguang International Inc. is an educational consulting services 
19  company headquartered in New York, New York. It provides services to Chinese students 
20 
already studying in the United States and those who are considering this option. It also provides 
21 
services to an affiliated company in China. Hanguang International filed an H-1B petition for a 
22 
position in the market research analyst occupation on or about April 2, 2019, which Defendant 
23 
USCIS denied on November 1, 2019 for, inter alia, failing to demonstrate that the position 
24 
satisfied 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A)(1) (2020), the first regulatory test for a specialty 
25 
26  occupation. 
27 
Pls. Am. Compl. for Decl. and Inj. Relief                                   Case No. 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   
 
Page 6 
  
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 39   Filed 07/20/20   Page 7 of 26
 
 
16.  Defendant USCIS is a component of the Department of Homeland Security,   
1 
6 U.S.C. § 271, and an agency within the meaning of the APA, 5 U.S.C. § 551(1). USCIS is 
2 
3  responsible for adjudicating immigration benefits, including H-1B petitions. USCIS denied 
4  Plaintiffs’ H-1B petitions. 
5 
17.  Defendant Kenneth T. Cuccinelli is, at the time this Complaint is filed, the Senior 
6 
Official Performing Duties of the Director, as the position of USCIS Director remains vacant. In 
7 
this position, he is responsible for overseeing the adjudication of immigration benefits and 
8 
establishing and implementing governing policies. The USCIS Director has ultimate 
9 
responsibility for the adjudication of H-1B petitions. Defendant Cuccinelli is sued in his official 
10 
11  capacity. 
12 
OVERVIEW OF THE LAW AND ADMINISTRATIVE  
DECISIONMAKING PROCESS 
13 
 
18.  Congress established a nonimmigrant classification to permit noncitizens to 
14 
15  temporarily perform services in the United States in specialty occupations. 8 U.S.C. 
16 
§ 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b). This nonimmigrant classification is commonly referred to as H-1B.  
17 
19.  A U.S. employer must follow a multi-step, two-agency process to obtain an H-1B 
18 
classification for a position it seeks to fill with a foreign worker. First, it must file a Labor 
19 
Condition Application with the U.S. Department of Labor in which it attests to standards to 
20 
which it will adhere. On this application, the employer must identify the Standard Occupational 
21 
22  Classification (SOC) code and occupational title of the position it seeks to fill. The SOC system 
23  is a federal statistical standard used by federal agencies to classify workers into occupational 
24 
categories for the purpose of collecting, calculating, or disseminating data.  
25 
20.  Upon the Department of Labor’s certification of the Labor Condition Application, 
26 
the U.S. employer will file it and an H-1B petition with Defendant USCIS. In its H-1B petition, 
27 
Pls. Am. Compl. for Decl. and Inj. Relief                                   Case No. 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   
 
Page 7 
  
 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 39   Filed 07/20/20   Page 8 of 26
 
 
the U.S. employer petitioner must demonstrate by a preponderance of the evidence that the 
1 
position it seeks to fill is in a specialty occupation.  
2 
3  21.  A “specialty occupation” is one that requires the “(A) theoretical and practical 
4  application of a body of highly specialized knowledge, and (B) attainment of a bachelor’s or 
5 
higher degree in the specific specialty (or its equivalent) as a minimum for entry into the 
6 
occupation in the United States.” 8 U.S.C. § 1184(i)(1). 
7 
22.  The regulatory definition of “specialty occupation” first repeats the statutory 
8 
definition and then provides a non-exhaustive list of fields as examples of specialty occupations:   
9 
Specialty occupation means an occupation which requires theoretical and practical 
10 
application of a body of highly specialized knowledge in fields of human endeavor 
11  including, but not limited to, architecture, engineering, mathematics, physical sciences, 
social sciences, medicine and health, education, business specialties, accounting, law, 
12 
theology, and the arts, and which requires the attainment of a bachelor's degree or higher 
in a specific specialty, or its equivalent, as a minimum for entry into the occupation in the 
13 
United States.  
14 
8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(ii) (2020). 
15 
23.  A proposed job must satisfy one—but only one—of four independent regulatory 
16 
tests to qualify as a specialty occupation. Relevant here is the first regulatory test, which is 
17 
satisfied if the petitioning U.S. employer demonstrates that:   
18 
A baccalaureate or higher degree or its equivalent is normally the minimum requirement 
19 
for entry into the particular position.

24  I.  BACKGROUND 
25  A.  The H-1B Visa 
26    The Immigration and Nationality Act allows employers to petition for foreign workers in 
27  specialty occupations to come to the United States to perform services or labor.  8 U.S.C. § 
28  1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b1); 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(1)(i).  The purpose of the H-1B provisions is to help 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 2 of 14
 
1  employers who cannot otherwise obtain needed business skills and abilities from the U.S. workforce 
2  by authorizing the temporary employment of qualified individuals who are not otherwise authorized 
3  to work in the United States.  8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b1); 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(1)(i).  A 
4  “specialty occupation” is an occupation that requires theoretical and practical application of a body 
5  of highly specialized knowledge and a bachelor’s or higher degree in the specific specialty (or its 
6  equivalent).  8 U.S.C. § 1184(i)(1); 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(i)(A)(1).  The position must meet one of 
7  the four criteria to constitute a specialty occupation position: 
 
8  (1) A baccalaureate or higher degree or its equivalent is normally the 
minimum requirement for entry into the particular position;  
9  (2) The degree requirement is common to the industry in parallel 
positions among similar organizations or, in the alternative, an 
10  employer may show that its particular position is so complex or 
unique that it can be performed only by an individual with a 
11  degree; 
(3) The employer normally requires a degree or its equivalent for the 
  12  position; or 
a
tr in (4) The nature of the specific duties are so specialized and complex 
uoro 13  that  knowledge  required  to  perform  the  duties  is  usually 
Cfi

19  after identifying the occupation within which the position falls, USCIS consults the Occupational 
20  Outlook Handbook (“OOH”), which provides for that position.  Id. at ¶ 25.  Plaintiffs allege the 
21  OOH establishes that the market research analyst position satisfies the first regulatory test for a

3  concluding this indicates the degree requirement is not in a specific specialty.  Id. at ¶¶ 28, 29. 
4  Plaintiffs allege that they are aware of at least 60 H-1B market research analyst petitions that 
5  were denied in the past three calendar years.  Id. at ¶ 32.  In all the denials, USCIS stated the same 
6  reasoning and similar language, finding that the OOH did not establish that a market research analyst 
7  was a specialty occupation under the first regulatory test.  Id. at ¶¶ 32, 63.  These decisions allegedly

9  this basis during this period and the pattern and practice is continuing.  Id. at ¶¶ 32, 64. 
10  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
11  A.  Motion to Sever Pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 21  
12  Rule 20(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (“FRCP”) permits plaintiffs to join in one 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  action if: “(A) they assert any right to relief jointly, severally, or in the alternative with respect to or 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  arising out of the same transaction, occurrence, or series of transactions or occurrences; and (B) any 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  question of law or fact common to all plaintiffs will arise in the action.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 20(a)(1).  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  If the test for permissive joinder is not satisfied, a court has discretion to sever the misjoined parties, 
S d nr
ee 17  so long as no substantial right will be prejudiced by the severance.  Coughlin v. Rogers, 130 F.3d 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  1348, 1350 (9th Cir. 1997); see Fed. R. Civ. P. 21.  “Even once these requirements are met, a district 
19  court must examine whether permissive joinder would ‘comport with the principles of fundamental 
20  fairness’ or would result in prejudice to either side.”  Coleman v. Quaker Oats Co., 232 F.3d 1271, 
21  1296 (9th Cir. 2000) (quoting Desert Empire Bank v. Insurance Co. of N. Am., 623 F.2d 1371, 1375 
22  (9th Cir. 1980)).  “[P]ermissive joinder is to be construed liberally in order to promote trial 
23  convenience and to expedite the final determination of disputes, thereby preventing multiple 
24  lawsuits.”  League to Save Lake Tahoe v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency, 558 F.2d 914, 917 (9th 
25  Cir. 1977). 
26  B.  Motion to Dismiss Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1) 
27    A defendant may move to dismiss an action for lack of subject matter jurisdiction under 
28  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1).  When a defendant moves to dismiss a complaint for lack 
4 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 5 of 14
 
1  of subject matter jurisdiction, the plaintiff bears the burden of proving that jurisdiction exists.  
2  Thornhill Pub. Co., Inc. v. General Tel. & Electronics Corp., 594 F.2d 730, 733 (9th Cir. 1979).  “A 
3  Rule 12(b)(1) jurisdictional attack may be facial or factual.”  Safe Air for Everyone v. Meyer, 373 
4  F.3d 1035, 1039 (9th Cir. 2004) (citation omitted).  “In a facial attack, the challenger asserts that the 
5  allegations contained in a complaint are insufficient on their face to invoke federal jurisdiction.”  Id.  
6  Courts resolve a facial attack “as it would a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6): Accepting the 
7  plaintiff’s allegations as true and drawing all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff’s favor, the court 
8  determines whether the allegations are sufficient as a legal matter to invoke the court’s jurisdiction.”  
9  Leite v. Crane Co., 749 F.3d 1117, 1121 (9th Cir. 2014) (citation omitted).  On the other hand, “in 
10  a factual attack, the challenger disputes the truth of the allegations that, by themselves, would 
11  otherwise invoke federal jurisdiction.”  Safe Air for Everyone, 373 F.3d at 1039.   
  12  C.  Motion to Dismiss Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(3) 
a
tr in
uoro 13    A party may bring a motion to dismiss an action for improper venue under Federal Rule of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Civil Procedure 12(b)(3).  If venue is found to be improper, the court “shall dismiss, or if it be in 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  the interest of justice, transfer such case to any district or division in which it could have been 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  brought.”  28 U.S.C. § 1406(a).  When venue is challenged, the plaintiff bears the burden of 
S d nr
ee 17  demonstrating that venue is proper.  Piedmont Label Co. v. Sun Garden Packing Co., 598 F.2d 491, 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  496 (9th Cir. 1979) (“Plaintiff had the burden of showing that venue was properly laid in the 
19  Northern District of California.”).   
20    The question of whether venue is wrong or improper is generally governed by 28 U.S.C. § 
21  1391.  Atlantic Marine Const. Co., Inc. v. U.S. Dist. Court for Western Dist. Of Texas, 571 U.S. 49, 
22  55 (2013) (internal quotations omitted).  In cases brought against agencies, officers, or employees 
23  of the United States, venue is proper “in any judicial district in which (A) a defendant in the action 
24  resides, (B) a substantial part of the events or omissions giving rise to the claim occurred, or a 
25  substantial part of property that is the subject of the action is situated, or (C) the plaintiff resides if 
26  no real property is involved in the action.”  28 U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1).  If the case falls within one of 
27  the three categories, venue is proper.  See Atlantic Marine Const. Co., Inc., 571 U.S. at 56.

1  III.  DISCUSSION 
2  A.  Severance 
3  Defendants contend that severance as to all four named Plaintiffs is warranted in the instant 
4  litigation because the claims do not arise out of the same transaction or occurrence and do not present 
5  common questions of law or fact.  Dkt. 47 at 9, 16.  Plaintiffs dispute Defendants’ assertion of 
6  severance, contending that this case was brought as a class action to raise issues that are common to 
7  similarly situated parties.  Dkt. 48 at 7.  Further, Plaintiffs contend they are seeking a right to relief 
8  arising out of the same transaction, occurrence, or series of transactions or occurrences and a 
9  common question of law.  Id. at 8.  In its reply, Defendants argue that while there may be similar 
10  issues of law, that does not mean the cases involve the same transaction, occurrence, or series of 
11  transactions or occurrences.  Dkt. 49 at 7. 
  12  1.  Same  Transaction,  Occurrence,  or  Series  of  Transactions  or 
a
tr in Occurrences 
uoro 13 
C tfila The first prong of the Rule 21 severance standard refers to “similarity in the factual 
cC 14 
i
rts fo background of a claim.”  Coughlin, 130 F.3d at 1350.  “By its terms, this provision requires factual 
iD tc 15 
 sir similarity in the allegations supporting Plaintiffs’ claims.”  Visendi v. Bank of America, N.A., 733 
et
tatsiD 16 
S d nr F.3d 863, 870 (9th Cir. 2013).  Even though there may be different occurrences, joinder in a single 
ee 17 
th
intr case may be appropriate where the claims involve enough related operative facts.  Nguyen v. CTS 
Uo
N 18 
Electronics Manufacturing Solutions Inc., 301 F.R.D. 337, 341 (N.D. Cal. 2014). 
19 
In Coughlin, 49 plaintiffs brought suit against the Immigration and Naturalization Service 
20 
(“INS”) and its then-Director, Richard Rogers, alleging that defendants unreasonably delayed 
21 
adjudicating plaintiffs’ applications and petitions.  Coughlin, 130 F.3d at 1349.  The plaintiffs’ 
22 
applications or petitions fell into six distinct categories, with some applications and petitions brought 
23 
by United States citizens on behalf of an alien spouse or child, others brought by aliens on behalf of 
24 
themselves.  Id. at 1349–50.  In short, the applications and petitions were significantly different from 
25 
one another.  On these facts, the Ninth Circuit reasoned that each plaintiff “waited a different length 
26 
of time, suffering a different duration of alleged delay” and in some instances, the delay was disputed 
27 
and varied from case to case.  Id. at 1350.  The Ninth Circuit found that the existence of a common 
28 
6

1  allegation of delay alone did not suffice to create a common transaction or occurrence.  Id. 
2  Defendants argue that as in Coughlin, each applicant in the instant case presents a different 
3  factual situation and therefore each must receive personalized attention by the agency and the Court.  
4  Dkt. 47 at 17.  Plaintiffs contend that Coughlin highlights an important difference with the instant 
5  litigation, which is challenging a uniform pattern and practice of Defendants that adversely affects 
6  all Plaintiffs.  Dkt. 48 at 9.  The Court agrees with Plaintiffs.  The plaintiffs in Coughlin had not 
7  alleged a pattern or policy of delay by the INS in dealing with the applications or petitions, but 
8  rather, claimed that in specific instances, the applications and petitions were not addressed in a 
9  timely manner.  Coughlin, 130 F.3d at 1350.  In severing the plaintiffs’ claims, the Ninth Circuit 
10  purposefully recognized that the plaintiffs “do not allege that their claims arise out of a systemic 
11  pattern of events and, therefore, arise from the same transaction or occurrence.”  Id. 
12  Here, Plaintiffs are not merely claiming that in specific instances, the H-1B petitions they 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  filed on behalf of noncitizens they sought to hire in the market research analyst occupation were 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  denied.  Rather, Plaintiffs are challenging USCIS’ pattern and practice of arbitrarily and unlawfully 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  denying H-1B petitions for market research analysts.  Dkt. 39 ¶¶ 1, 6, 29, 32, 65; Dkt. 48 at 8.  The 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  fact that H-1B denials were adjudicated at separate USCIS service centers across the country does 
S d nr
ee 17  not  undermine  Plaintiffs’  argument  that  the  denials  involve  the  same  series  of  occurrences.  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Accordingly, the Court concludes that Plaintiffs alleging their claims arise out of a systemic pattern 
19  of events and result in denial of the H-1B petitions for the market research analyst occupation are 
20  sufficiently related to constitute a common transaction or occurrence. 
21  2.  Common Questions of Law or Fact 
22    The second prong is whether any common questions of law or fact will arise in the action.  
23  “Commonality under Rule 20(a)(1)(B) is not a particularly stringent test” and requires only a single 
24  common question.  Nguyen, 301 F.R.D. at 341 (citations omitted). 
25    Defendants argue that each plaintiff employer has a “separate case to plead” and even if a 
26  decision on the common issue of the validity of the government’s application of a specific regulation 
27  or statute might impact each Plaintiff’s individual case, it will not necessarily be dispositive.  Dkt. 
28  47 at 19.  Plaintiffs counter by pointing to the common question of law of whether Defendants are 
7 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 8 of 14
 
1  denying H-1B petitions for market research analysts based on a misinterpretation of the statutory 
2  term “specific specialty” and the first regulatory test as well as an erroneous reading of the OOH 
3  profile for market research analysts.  Dkt. 48 at 9.  
4    Coughlin is both distinguishable and instructive for the second prong as well.  In addressing 
5  this prong, the Ninth Circuit again referenced that the plaintiffs are not alleging that Defendants 
6  engaged in a policy of delay.  Coughlin, 130 F.3d at 1351.  Additionally, the Ninth Circuit concluded 
7  that plaintiffs failed the second prong of the test because each category of Plaintiffs filed different 
8  applications, petitions, or forms with different legal standards as to each type of application or 
9  petition.  Id.  As a result, each applicant or petitioner presented a different factual situation and 
10  required personalized attention by the INS.  Id.  For the reasons stated in Section III.A.1 above, the 
11  instant case is easily distinguishable. 
12  Stellar IT Solutions, Inc. v. United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, No. 18-cv-
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  2015 (RC), 2019 WL 3430746 (D.D.C. July 30, 2019) is also distinguishable.  Plaintiff InDepth 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Engineering Solutions, LLC filed a motion to intervene in a case brought by Stellar IT Solutions, 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Inc., who had filed a lawsuit after the company’s H-1B visa on behalf of a software engineer was 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  denied.  Id. at *2–3.  The district court found that Indepth’s motion to intervene did not raise 
S d nr
ee 17  common questions of law or fact as it did not appear that the two petitions shared “a single piece of 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  evidence in common” and the two job positions were different.  Id. at 4.  Furthermore, Stellar IT’s 
19  case involved an additional legal question that was not at issue in InDepth’s case.  Id. 
20  In direct contrast to Stellar IT Solutions, the instant litigation is not simply about the denial 
21  of one employer’s H-1B petition.  Rather, Plaintiffs are claiming USCIS has a pattern and practice 
22  of misinterpreting the OOH’s profile of a market research analyst and has engaged in a systemic 
23  pattern or practice of unlawful decision-making.  Dkt. 39 ¶¶ 6, 29, 32, 65; Dkt. 48 at 14, 16–17.  
24  Further, the claims are specific to the market research analyst occupation and all involve the first 
25  regulatory test which authorizes a position to qualify as a specialty occupation.  Dkt. 39 ¶¶ 3–6; Dkt. 
26  48 at 8.  As a result, the claims involve common questions of law regarding USCIS’ alleged pattern 
27  and practice of unlawful decision-making in regards to the H-1B petitions for the market research 
28  analyst occupation.  Accordingly, Defendants’ motion to sever is DENIED.  
8 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 9 of 14
 
1  B.  Mootness 
2    Defendants contend that the instant litigation is moot as to MadKudu and Quick Fitting 
3  because they obtained the H-1B visa approvals they sought and therefore should be dismissed from 
4  this action.  Dkt. 47 at 20–21.  Defendants further contend that the “voluntary cessation” and 
5  “capable of repetition, yet evading review” exceptions to the mootness doctrine do not apply.  Id. at 
6  21.  MadKudu and Quick Fitting do not dispute that their H-1B decisions were later reversed and 
7  the H-1B petitions were ultimately approved.  Dkt. 39 ¶¶ 39, 46.  However, MadKudu and Quick 
8  Fitting dispute Defendants’ assertion of mootness and argue that they retain a personal stake in the 
9  case.  Dkt. 48 at 15–16.  Plaintiffs also assert this Court can grant effective relief to 2nd Street and 
10  Hanguang International and the putative class.  Id.  Finally, Plaintiffs argue that their claims satisfy 
11  two of the exceptions to the mootness doctrine: the “voluntary cessation” and “capable of repetition 
12  yet evading review” exceptions.  Id. at 16. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  1.  Voluntary Cessation 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Defendants contend that the voluntary cessation doctrine does not apply here because USCIS 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  approved MadKudu and Quick Fitting’s H-1B petitions that were at issue in this litigation and there 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  is “no likelihood of recurrence of the challenged activity.”  Dkt. 47 at 21 (internal quotations 
S d nr
ee 17  omitted).  Further, Defendants contend that any claim by MadKudu and Quick Fitting that USCIS 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  will deny their future H-1B extension petitions for the same market research analyst positions is 
19  speculative.  Id.  
20   “A case becomes moot . . . when the issues presented are no longer live or the parties lack 
21  a legally cognizable interest in the outcome.”  Am. Diabetes Ass’n v. United States Dep’t of the 
22  Army, 938 F.3d 1147, 1152 (9th Cir. 2019) (citing Rosebrock v. Mathis, 745 F.3d 963, 971 (9th Cir. 
23  2014) (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).  “It is well settled that a defendant’s 
24  voluntary cessation of a challenged practice does not deprive a federal court of its power to 
25  determine the legality of the practice.”  Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), 
26  Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 189 (2000) (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).  “In accordance 
27  with this principle, the standard we have announced for determining whether a case has been mooted 
28  by the defendant’s voluntary conduct is stringent: A case might become moot if subsequent events 
9 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 10 of 14
 
1  made it absolutely clear that the allegedly wrongful behavior could not reasonably be expected to 
2  recur.”  Id. (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).  The “heavy burden” of persuading the 
3  court that the challenged conduct cannot reasonably be expected to recur lies with the party asserting 
4  mootness.  Id. (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).  In order for this exception to apply, 
5  “the defendant’s voluntary cessation must have arisen because of the litigation.”  Public Utilities 
6  Comm’n of State of Cal. v. F.E.R.C., 100 F.3d 1451, 1460 (9th Cir. 1996) (citation omitted). 
7    In Sze v. I.N.S., 153 F.3d 1005 (9th Cir. 1998), overruled in part by United States v. 
8  Hovsepian, 359 F.3d 1144 (9th Cir. 2004), the plaintiffs asserted that the INS failed to make a 
9  determination to grant or deny their applications within the required timeframe.  During the 
10  pendency of the action, the INS naturalized some of the named plaintiffs.  Id. at 1008.  The plaintiffs 
11  asserted that the timing of the INS’ decisions to naturalize the named plaintiffs indicate the 
12  applications were approved because of the litigation.  Id.  The Ninth Circuit reasoned that it appeared 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  that the INS acted on the naturalization applications “in due course, albeit significantly delayed due 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  course” and Plaintiffs demonstrated “no more than correlation” and failed to show causation.  Id.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Further, the Ninth Circuit reasoned that because the INS altered the naturalization application 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  process, the class of potential plaintiffs “has effectively been closed” and there is “little likelihood 
S d nr
ee 17  of recurrence of the challenged activity.”  Id. at 1008–09 (internal quotations omitted). 
th
intr
Uo
N 18    In contrast to the plaintiffs in Sze who had not received a determination in their applications 
19  when the lawsuit was filed, USCIS denied Plaintiffs’ H-1B petitions prior to this lawsuit.  After the 
20  initial denials in their H-1B petitions and less than four weeks after the lawsuit was filed, Plaintiffs 
21  argue that USCIS took the “extraordinary, sua sponte step” of reopening and re-adjudicating 
22  MadKudu and Quick Fitting’s denied petitions.  Dkt. 48 at 19.  Plaintiffs contend that this timing 
23  demonstrates that Defendants took this action specifically in response to the lawsuit and that 
24  Defendants have failed to show any evidence showing the contrary.  Id.  Further, Plaintiffs point out 
25  that Defendants have sought and continue to seek dismissal of the lawsuit based upon the approval 
26  of those petitions.  Id.  Defendants state that USCIS’ sua sponte reopening and approval of their 
27  cases was not “extraordinary,” acknowledging that it was “not uncommon for the agency to 
28  reconsider its initial decision following the commencement of a lawsuit, and represents a good faith 
10 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 11 of 14
 
1  effort by the parties to conserve judicial resources by administratively resolving the issues in the 
2  case in lieu of litigation.”  Dkt. 49 at 12.  Defendants further argue that because they only reopened 
3  and approved two of the four named Plaintiffs’ H-1B petitions, USCIS’ actions could not have been 
4  in direct response to the instant litigation.  Id. at 13.  The Court does not find this latter point 
5  persuasive.  Rather, the timing of USCIS’ approval of two of the Plaintiffs’ petitions along with 
6  USCIS’ acknowledgment that it often revisits petitions following the commencement of a lawsuit 
7  together demonstrate that USCIS’ voluntary cessation arose because of the instant litigation.  
8    The Court also disagrees with Defendants’ assertion that there is no likelihood of recurrence 
9  of the challenged activity.  Unlike in Sze where some of the named plaintiffs were naturalized and 
10  the class of potential plaintiffs effectively closed due to an alteration of the naturalization application 
11  process, there is a likelihood that the named Plaintiffs in the instant litigation will experience the 
12  challenged activity again.  In Sze, once plaintiffs received their naturalization, it was “highly 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  unlikely that they would ever have to repeat the process.”  Sze, 153 F.3d at 1009.  However, 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  MadKudu and Quick Fitting have both asserted they plan to file additional H-1B petitions for the 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  continuation of their respective market research analysts’ employment.  Dkt. 48 at 16–17; Dkt. 48-
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  1 at ¶ 10; Dkt. 48-2 at ¶ 7.  Moreover, there is a likelihood that similarly situated employers will 
S d nr
ee 17  submit H-1B petitions to hire a new employee or to keep an employee in the market research analyst 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  position.  As such, the allegedly wrongful behavior could reasonably be expected to recur whenever 
19  employers submit H-1B petitions for the market research analyst occupation.  Consequently, the 
20  Court does not find that Defendants have overcome the “heavy burden” of persuading the Court that 
21  the challenged conduct cannot reasonably be expected to recur and finds that the voluntary cessation 
22  exception applies.  
23    Further, Defendants’ argument that this case is moot ignores the requests for relief and 
24  Plaintiffs’ assertions that they are challenging USCIS’ denial of H-1B petitions on behalf of 
25  themselves and all others who are similarly situated.  Dkt. 39 ¶ 59; Dkt. 48 at 15–16; see Al Otro 
26  Lado, Inc. v. Nielsen, 327 F. Supp. 3d 1284, 1297 (S.D. Cal. 2018) (finding that the plaintiffs sought 
27  other forms of relief including declaratory judgment that defendants’ “policies, practices, acts and/or 
28  omissions” violate various laws and Defendants made “no meaningful attempt to argue that their 
11 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 12 of 14
 
1  agreement to process the Individual Plaintiffs moots these requests for injunctive and declaratory 
2  relief”).  Indeed, in PayJoy, Inc. v. Cuccinelli, No. 19-cv-03977-HSG, 2020 WL 1812193, at *2 
3  (N.D. Cal. Apr. 9, 2020), the district court deemed it no longer had jurisdiction over the case only 
4  “[b]ecause the exact relief sought in this action, requiring Defendant to approve a H-1B petition” 
5  had already been granted (emphasis added).  Here, Plaintiffs are seeking “a declaration that 
6  Defendants’ adjudicatory practices with respect to H-1B petitions for Market Research Analysts 
7  violates the APA, the INA and the regulations” and are seeking “an order that they immediately 
8  adjudicate all such petitions in accordance with the law.”  Dkt. 48 at 15–17.  “A case becomes moot 
9  only when it is impossible for a court to grant any effectual relief whatever to the prevailing party.”  
10  Knox v. S.E.I.U, Local 1000, 567 U.S. 298, 307 (citations and internal quotations omitted).  “[A]s 
11  long as the parties have a concrete interest, however small, in the outcome of the litigation, the case 
12  is not moot.”  Ellis v. Brotherhood of Ry., Airline and S.S. Clerks, Freight Handlers, Express and 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Station Emps, et al., 466 U.S. 435, 442 (1984).   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Additionally, even if the claim of the named plaintiff has become moot, the controversy may 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  still exist between a named defendant and a member of the class represented by the named plaintiff.  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  See Sosna v. Iowa, 419 U.S. 393, 402–03 (1975).  Indeed, “the putative class action nature of this 
S d nr
ee 17  case does change the Court’s analysis” and “[c]ourts are sensitive to assertions of mootness in the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  class action context.”  Al Otro Lado, Inc., 327 F. Supp. 3d at 1303.  Plaintiffs brought this pattern 
19  or practice claim as a class action and the operative complaint is on behalf of the four named 
20  Plaintiffs and similarly situated H-1B petitioners.  Dkt. 39 ¶¶ 1, 59.  As a result, this case is not moot 
21  given that it remains possible for the Court to grant effectual relief to the named Plaintiffs and the 
22  similarly situated H-1B petitioners.  Because the Court finds that the voluntary cessation exception 
23  to mootness applies in this case, the Court need not consider whether the “capable of repetition, yet 
24  evading review” exception to the mootness doctrine applies.  Accordingly, Defendants’ motion to 
25  dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(1) is DENIED.  
26  IV.  VENUE   
27    Defendants contend that Plaintiffs 2nd Street, located in Los Angeles, California, and 
28  Hanguang International, operating out of New York, New York, do not have claims that are 
12 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 13 of 14
 
1  appropriately venued in this District and must be dismissed entirely from this case.  Dkt. 47 at 22.  
2  Specifically, Defendants argue that when there are multiple parties and/or multiple claims in an 
3  action, plaintiffs must establish that venue is proper “as to each defendant and as to each claim.”  Id. 
4  at 23.  Plaintiffs dispute Defendants’ assertion, stating the case was filed in accordance with 28 
5  U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1)(C) because MadKudu resides in this District and no real property is involved.  
6  Dkt. 48 at 22; Dkt. 39 ¶ 9.  Plaintiffs further contend that because the instant action was filed as a 
7  nationwide class action and 2nd Street and Hanguang International are appropriately joined, venue 
8  is appropriate.  Dkt. 48 at 22.  In its reply, Defendants argue that because MadKudu’s claims are 
9  moot, Plaintiffs have not demonstrated that venue is proper and the Court should dismiss 2nd Street 
10  and Hanguang International entirely from this case.  Dkt. 49 at 14–15. 
11    “Each court faced with the same issue has interpreted ‘the plaintiff’ to mean ‘any plaintiff,’ 
12  finding that Congress intended to broaden the number of districts in which suits could be brought 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  against government entities.”  Sidney Coal Co., Inc. v. Social Sec. Admin., 427 F.3d 336, 344–45 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  (6th Cir. 2005).  “For purposes of § 1391(e)(1)(C), the clear weight of federal authority holds that 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  venue is proper in a multi-plaintiff case if any plaintiff resides in the District.”  Californians for 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Renewable Energy v. United States EPA, No. C 15-3293 SBA, 2018 WL 1586211, at *19 (N.D. 
S d nr
ee 17  Cal. Mar. 30, 2018).  Indeed, “requiring every plaintiff in an action against the federal government 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  or an agent thereof to independently meet section 1391(e)’s standards would result in an unnecessary 
19  multiplicity of litigation.”  Exxon Corp. v. F.T.C., 588 F.2d 895, 898 (3d Cir. 1978), overruled in 
20  part on other grounds by Reifer v. Westport Ins. Corp., 751 F.3d 129 (3d Cir. 2014).   
21    As stated above, the Court has denied Defendants’ motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 
22  12(b)(1) based on mootness regarding MadKudu and Quick Fitting’s claims and MadKudu remains 
23  one of the named Plaintiffs in this action.  Because MadKudu resides in the Northern District of 
24  California and no real property is involved in this action, venue is proper before this Court.  See 28 
25  U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1); Californians for Renewable Energy, 2018 WL 1586211, at *5–6 (finding that 
26  only one Plaintiff must reside within the forum district for venue purposes); Mosleh v. Pompeo, No. 
27  1:19-cv-00656-LJO-BAM, 2019 WL 2524407, at *1 (E.D. Cal. June 19, 2019) (finding venue was 
28  proper  before  the  Court  because  at  least  one plaintiff resided  in  that  district);  Dkt.  39 ¶  9.  
13 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 51   Filed 09/14/20   Page 14 of 14
 
1  Accordingly, Defendants’ motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(3) is DENIED. 
2  V.  CONCLUSION 
3    For the reasons discussed, the motion to sever and motion to dismiss are DENIED. 
4  SO ORDERED. 
5  Dated: September 14, 2020

uoro 13  I.  INTRODUCTION 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Plaintiffs MadKudu Inc., Quick Fitting, Inc., 2nd Street USA, Inc., and Hanguang 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  International Inc. (collectively, “Plaintiffs”) bring this lawsuit on behalf of themselves and 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  similarly aggrieved U.S. employers against Defendants U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services 
S d nr
ee 17  (“USCIS”) and Kenneth T. Cuccinelli in his official capacity (collectively, “Defendants”).  Dkt. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  39 (“First Amended Complaint”).  Before the Court is Plaintiffs’ motion for class certification.  
19  Dkt. 40 (“Motion”).   
20    All parties have consented to the jurisdiction of a magistrate judge.  Dkts. 13, 33, 34, 43.  
21  The Court held a hearing on October 27, 2020.  Dkt. 58.  After considering the Parties’ 
22  submissions, arguments at the hearing, the case file, and relevant law, the Court GRANTS IN 
23  PART Plaintiffs’ motion for class certification for the reasons discussed below. 
24  II.  BACKGROUND 
25  A.  The H-1B Visa 
26    The Immigration and Nationality Act allows employers to petition for foreign workers in 
27  specialty occupations to come to the United States to perform services or labor. 8 U.S.C. § 
28  1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b1); 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(1)(i).  The purpose of the H-1B provisions is to help 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 59   Filed 11/17/20   Page 2 of 17
 
1  employers who cannot otherwise obtain needed business skills and abilities from the U.S. 
2  workforce by authorizing the temporary employment of qualified individuals who are not 
3  otherwise authorized to work in the United States. 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b1); 8 C.F.R. § 
4  214.2(h)(1)(i).  A “specialty occupation” is an occupation that requires theoretical and practical 
5  application of a body of highly specialized knowledge and a bachelor’s or higher degree in the 
6  specific specialty (or its equivalent). 8 U.S.C. § 1184(i)(1); 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(i)(A)(1).  The 
7  position must meet one of the four criteria to constitute a specialty occupation position: 
8   
(1) A baccalaureate or higher degree or its equivalent is normally the 
9  minimum requirement for entry into the particular position; 
(2) The degree requirement is common to the industry in parallel 
10  positions  among  similar  organizations  or,  in  the  alternative,  an 
employer may show that its particular position is so complex or 
11  unique that it can be performed only by an individual with a degree; 
(3) The employer normally requires a degree or its equivalent for the 
  12  position; or 
a
tr in (4) The nature of the specific duties are so specialized and complex 
uoro 13  that knowledge required to perform the duties is usually associated 
Cfi
 tla with the attainment of a baccalaureate or higher degree. 
cC 14 
i
rts fo   8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A). 
iD tc 15 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  B.  Interim Final Rule (“IFR”) 
S d nr
ee 17    On October 8, 2020, while briefing on the Motion was in progress, the Department of 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Homeland Security (“DHS”) issued an interim final rule amending the regulations for H-1B 
19  petitions.  The IFR will take effect on December 7, 2020 for all H-1B petitions, including 
20  amended petitions or petition extensions, filed on or after that date.  See Strengthening the H-1B 
21  Nonimmigrant Visa Classification Program, 85 Fed. Reg. 63,918 (Oct. 8, 2020).  In relevant part, 
22  DHS is revising the regulatory definition and standards for a “specialty occupation” to align with 
23  the statutory definition of “specialty occupation.”  Id. at 63,924.  Specifically, the rule “amends the 
24  definition of a ‘specialty occupation’ at 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(ii) to clarify that there must be a 
25  direct relationship between the required degree field(s) and the duties of the position” and 
26  “clarifies that a position would not qualify as a specialty occupation if attainment of a general 
27  degree, without further specialization, is sufficient to qualify for the position.”  Id. at 63,924–25, 
28  63,964 (“Specialty occupation means an occupation that requires . . . [t]he attainment of a U.S. 
2 

Case 5:20-cv-02653-SVK   Document 59   Filed 11/17/20   Page 3 of 17
 
1  bachelor’s degree or higher in a directly related specific specialty, or its equivalent, as a minimum 
2  for entry into the occupation in the United States.”).  Further, DHS is eliminating the term 
3  “normally” from 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(h)(4)(iii)(A), meaning “that the petitioner will have to establish 
4  that the bachelor’s degree in a specific specialty or its equivalent is a minimum requirement for 
5  entry into the occupation in the United States by showing that this is always the requirement for 
6  the occupation as a whole . . .”  Id. at 63,926. 
7  C.  Named Plaintiffs 
8    Plaintiff MadKudu Inc. (“MadKudu”) is a marketing analytics software corporation 
9  headquartered in Mountain View, California.  Dkt. 40 at 12; Dkt. 40-2 ¶¶ 2–3.  On or about April 
10  2, 2019, MadKudu filed an H-1B petition for a market research analyst position.  Dkt. 40 at 13; 
11  Dkt. 40-2 ¶¶ 4–6.  USCIS denied the petition on February 24, 2020, stating that MadKudu failed 
12  to demonstrate that the position was a specialty occupation under any of the independent 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  regulatory tests.  Dkt. 40 at 13; Dkt. 40-2 ¶ 7; Dkt. 40-3.  Specifically, USCIS determined that 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  MadKudu’s petition did not meet the first regulatory test because the Occupational Outlook 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Handbook (“OOH”) did not show that market research analyst positions normally require a 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  minimum of a bachelor’s degree or its equivalent in a specific specialty at the entry level.  Dkt. 40 
S d nr
ee 17  at 13; Dkt. 40-3 at 4–5.  On May 11, 2020, USCIS approved MadKudu’s petition without 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  explanation.  Dkt. 40 at 13; Dkt. 40-11 at 2–3. 
19    Plaintiff Quick Fitting, Inc. (“Quick Fitting”), a plumbing fittings supplier headquartered 
20  in Warwick, Rhode Island, also filed an H-1B petition for a market research analyst position on or 
21  about August 20, 2019.  Dkt. 40 at 14; Dkt. 40-4 ¶¶ 2–5.  On January 23, 2020, USCIS denied the 
22  petition, stating Quick Fitting failed to demonstrate that the position was a specialty occupation 
23  under any of the independent regulatory tests.  Dkt. 40 at 14; Dkt. 40-4 ¶¶ 6–7; Dkt. 40-5.  
24  Specifically, USCIS determined that Quick Fitting’s petition did not meet the first regulatory test 
25  because the OOH did not show that market research analyst positions normally require a minimum 
26  of a bachelor’s degree or its equivalent in a specific specialty at the entry level.  Dkt. 40 at 14; 
27  Dkt. 40-5 ¶¶ 4–5.  On May 11, 2020, USCIS approved Quick Fitting’s H-1B petition without 
28  explanation.  Dkt. 40 at 15; Dkt. 40-11 at 4–5.   
3

1    Plaintiff 2nd Street USA, Inc. (“2nd Street”), a clothing corporation headquartered in Los 
2  Angeles, California, filed an H-1B petition for a market research analyst position on or about April 
3  11, 2019.  Dkt. 40 at 15–16; Dkt. 40-12 ¶¶ 2–5.  On September 12, 2019, USCIS denied 2nd 
4  Street’s H-1B petition under each of the independent regulatory tests and stated that the petition

27  The Court has the discretion to grant or deny class certification under Federal Rule of Civil 
28  Procedure 23.  Zinser v. Accufix Research Inst., Inc., 253 F.3d 1180, 1186 (9th Cir. 2001).

2  Higher Educ., 816 F.2d 458, 467 (9th Cir.1987), may excise portions of a plaintiffs [sic] class 
3  allegations, and may even decertify the class.”  Armstrong v. Davis, 275 F.3d 849, 871 n.28 (9th 
4  Cir. 2001), abrogated on other grounds by Johnson v. California, 543 U.S. 499, 125 S.Ct. 1141, 
5  160 L.Ed.2d 949 (2005), as recognized in B.K. by next friend Tinsley v. Snyder, 922 F.3d 957, 974 
6  (9th Cir. 2019).   
7  Rule 23 is a two-prong test.  First, Rule 23(a) provides that a class may only be certified if: 
8  “(1) the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable; (2) there are questions 
9  of law or fact common to the class; (3) the claims or defenses of the representative parties are 
10  typical of the claims or defenses of the class; and (4) the representative parties will fairly and 
11  adequately protect the interests of the class.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a).  These four requirements are 
12  commonly referred to as “numerosity,” “commonality,” “typicality,” and “adequacy.”  If all four 
 
a

S d nr

th

Uo
N 18  final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a 
19  whole.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2). 
20    The party seeking class certification bears the burden of proof in demonstrating that it has 
21  satisfied all four Rule 23(a) prerequisites and that their class lawsuit falls within one of the three 
22  types of actions permitted under Rule 23(b).  Zinser, 253 F.3d at 1186.  The failure to meet “any 
23  one of Rule 23’s requirements destroys the alleged class action.”  Rutledge v. Elec. Hose & 
24  Rubber Co., 511 F.2d 668, 673 (9th Cir. 1975).  Consequently, when considering whether to 
25  certify a class under Rule 23, district courts must perform “a rigorous analysis” to ensure that Rule 
26  23(a) has been satisfied.  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 350–51 (2011).  This 
27  “rigorous analysis” may require a court “to probe behind the pleadings before coming to rest on 
28  the certification question.”  Sandoval v. M1 Auto Collisions Ctrs., 309 F.R.D. 549, 560 (N.D. Cal.

2  certification question “will entail some overlap with the merits of the plaintiff’s underlying claim,”

10  “The test of typicality is whether other members have the same or similar injury, whether the

6  E.  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) 
7  Class actions must also satisfy one of three enumerated categories.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 
8  23(b)(1)-(3).  Here, Plaintiffs seek to certify under Rule 23(b)(2).  A class may be certified under 
9  Rule 23(b)(2) if “the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on the grounds that apply 
10  generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is 
11  appropriate respecting the class as a whole.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2).  “Class certification under 
12  Rule 23(b)(2) requires that the primary relief sought is declaratory or injunctive.”  Rodriguez, 591
